body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

This is a follow-up to the issue https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6676 and discusses optimizations to the function `__Pyx_ParseOptionalKeywords`

Basically I'm trying to optimize item instance creation in particular, but more cases are affected.

I open this issue to have a place for the discussion around this improvement.

Basically here is my current understanding of the topic:

## Two call conventions
Two call conventions are [used](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/call.html).
- tp_call: a tuple (args) and a dict (kwargs) is passed. `__init__` and `__cinit__` always use this convention.
- vectorcall: a tuple (args + kwargs values) and a tuple (kwnames keys) is passed. This is the convention used by default (because it is better for speed).

## Parameter validation
The callee has some validation to perform.

- If kwargs is a dict it must ensures the keys are unicode (or subclasses). It can be done either by iterating on each key and checking if they are unicode, or calling `PyArg_ValidateKeywordArguments`, which will have a fast path if it finds that the dict knows it only contains unicodes.
- No validation is needed on kwargs and kwnames for duplicate entries
- Validation is needed to check the kwargs and kwnames entries do not duplicate a positional parameters (args).

The current strategy is to validate only if not all keyword arguments are used. In other words, when **kwargs is an argument of the input function, it will always have this validation.

## Parameter association

In order to associate fast kwargs keys / kwnames, Cython currently relies on interned strings, which are strings which will always get the same PyObject for the same content (subclasses of str excluded). This enables to perform direct equality test on the PyObject pointer. Cython thus iterates over the names to find if one points to the same PyObject.

In the case where the keyword is not found, using this fast test, a slower path uses string comparison routines. The string size is used, and then comfirmed using a complete string comparison.

## The performance issue with the current approach

If **kwargs is not used, and assuming the typical call will not have errors, and will use unicode kwarg keys, the matching should be very fast, and duplicate entry validation is skipped.

On the other hand, when **kwargs is used for the function input, in other words there are keywords in kwnames/kwargs that are not present in the argument list, the current Cython code underperforms because:
- Duplicate parameter validation is performed, and for each keywords that should end up in **kwargs, multiple tests, up to a complete string comparison are performed against the parameter names.
- The new kwargs is built from scratch, inserting one by one the keys.

Optimizing **kwargs is important because it is often used for functions such as `__cinit__` and `__init__` when doing subclassing. This directly impacts the speed of item creation.

## How could speed be improved ?

Considering the case without **kwargs should be pretty good already, let's discuss only the case with **kwargs.

One key aspect is how to validate fast that there are no duplicated entries.

For parameter association, the interned string test enables almost always to find an exact match. But since it leads to some false negatives, it cannot be used to exclude duplication. We need instead some strategy that has no false negatives but may have false positives, then completed with an equality check in case of assumed match.

Remains a few options:
- Using the string size (current Cython strategy if CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_SIZE is set)
- Using the string hash (which seems to be sizeof(void*) for CPython), and is cached for each string.
- Reverse the loop and instead check for each positional parameter if they are in the keyword list. That's what CPython (getargs.c) seems to be doing. This enables to use the dict API to check the presence of the item.

The second aspect to improve speed is how to build the **kwargs as fast as possible.

When using the vectorcall method (kwnames), there doesn't seem to be another way than just iterating and inserting in a new dict the arguments.

However for the tp_call convention (which cover `__init__` and `__cinit__` which may have **kwargs), other alternatives are possible:
- When **kwargs contains exactly the same keys as what was given for the call (all other arguments were passed in *args), then one could copy it, or pass it as is. I suspect in most cases it could be passed as is, but not all (for instance I suspect `__cinit__` calls share the same **kwargs). Duplicating the dict however should be faster than iterating on the keys are inserting in the new dict, as it has a fast path.
In https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6676 I experimented exactly that
```cpp
    if (!*first_kw_arg && !kwds_is_tuple && kwds && kwds2) {
        // Check dict is unicode
        if (!PyArg_ValidateKeywordArguments(kwds)) goto bad; // Python already sets the error
        // Check for duplications
        name = argnames;
        while (*name) {
            int check = PyDict_Contains(kwds, **name);
            if (check < 0 && unlikely(PyErr_Occurred())) goto bad;
            if (check == 1) goto arg_passed_twice;
            name++;
        }
        // Fast copy
        if (PyDict_Update(kwds2, kwds) < 0)
           goto bad;
        return 0;
    }
```

This code, to be inserted at the top of `__Pyx_ParseOptionalKeywords` gave me visible speedups in item creation on some of my benchmarks for my library [DearCyGui](https://github.com/DearCyGui/DearCyGui/). I can get up to +40% speed when creating in a loop `dcg.Button` with 10 keyword arguments.

- When some values of positional arguments are missing, instead of iterating on the kwargs, one could use `PyDict_GetItem` to fetch them, then (after duplicating if needed the dict) remove them. Both operations can actually be done in one call using `PyDict_Pop`.

However this strategy might not be always be the best. If there are many positional arguments to find (and few extra keywords), iterating on the keywords, and building the new dict with remaining keywords might prove a better strategy.


## My current position

Keep the case without **kwargs as is. Else

### vectorcall convention

- Argument matching: same as now
- Validation: I would suggest to use the hash instead of the string length. To skip calls to CPython, it would be more efficient to compute the hashes when the module is imported, and store them. Similarly the loop can be modified to retrieve once the hash from CPython for each kwnames. While I believe hash would be more reliable, these same optimizations can be done too for length, and thus skip repeated function calls.
- Building the kwargs: same as now

### tp_call convention

When all positional arguments are already filled (no keyword to remove):
- Argument matching: None
- Validation: if many enough keywords relative to the number of positional arguments, use `PyDict_Contains` for each positional argument. If few keywords relative to the number of positional arguments, `PyDict_iter` + checking hashes of each positional argument, doing complete equality check if needed.
- Building the kwargs: `PyDict_Update`. When the target dict is new (which is the case here), a quick path is implemented (similar to `PyDict_Copy`).

When there are few positional arguments to retrieve among the keywords, and many keywords:
- Argument matching: `PyDict_Pop` (on duplicated kwargs if needed)
- Validation: depending on the number of positional parameters, same situation as above
- Building the kwargs: the resulting dict after the `PyDict_Pop` operations

When there are many positional arguments to retrieve among the keywords, and few expected remaining keys:
- Argument matching: Same as current code, with `PyDict_Iter`
- Validation: same as vectorcall
- Building the kwargs: same as vectorcall

Finally when **kwargs is unused (one use case is implementing `__cinit__`, but using only a subset of the arguments), building the **kwargs could be skipped, but this skipping logic should be done in a separate function.


As this is a complex topic, I may have some mistakes in my analysis, so please correct me if you find any issue and I will update the text with a mention.

## Side note

As it seemed the CPython code makes use a PyUnicode functions a lot, I wanted to see if it was really completly handling string subclasses.:
```python
def test(a, b, c):
    print(a, b, c)

class hou(str):
    def __hash__(self):
        return hash("a")
    def __str__(self):
        return "hello"

kwargs = {
    "a": 0,
    hou("b"): 1,
    hou("c"): 2
}
test(**kwargs)
print("b" == hou("b"))
print("b" == str(hou("b")))
print(hash("b") == hash(hou("b")))
print("b" in kwargs)
```
Output is 0, 1, 2 True False False False (python 3.13)

Given this result, well... looks like hash and dict ownership are not enough ?

```python
import operator
operator.call(test, (), **kwargs)

TypeError: test() got multiple values for argument 'a'
```
well I guess CPython is not consistent in its handling of strings between vectorcall and tp_call.

=> EDIT: Solved. removing () fixes the issue and the behaviour is consistent.

I would suggest to not mind too much about string subclasses and use hash if we want to.

### Describe the solution you'd like.

_No response_

### Describe alternatives you've considered.

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

comment_data.body: Quick comment regarding hash usage: the assumption is that the string keys in keyword argument dicts are almost always interned strings and thus hit the fast path that compares by identity. I wouldn't expect much from speeding up the fall back string comparisons that only happen for non interned strings.

> Quick comment regarding hash usage: the assumption is that the string keys in keyword argument dicts are almost always interned strings and thus hit the fast path that compares by identity. I wouldn't expect much from speeding up the fall back string comparisons that only happen for non interned strings.

When all keyword arguments are matched with an argument, I would expect the same. However when you explicitly accept **kwargs as input to your function, and indeed additional arguments are given to the function, then this path hits several times.

Let's imagine this function:
```python
def f(a, b, c, d, **kwargs)
```

If I call `f(0, 1, 2, 3, e=4, f=5, h=6)`, then all the combinations (a, e), (a, f) (a, h), (b, e), etc will be checked by `PyUnicode_Compare` with the current code. Using hashes for the comparison would avoid the calls.

I think the point with interning is that: 

* If you've manually written `f(0, 1, 2, 3, e=4, f=5, h=6)` in some code somewhere, that's probably caused `e`, `f` and `h` to be interned (because they're compile-time constants in some module).
* You're probably feeding them to some other function where they are named args, so they're probably interned because of that.
* Otherwise they're probably looked up in `kwds` with some known string constants (which probably means they're interned)
* In your toy example, they're length-1 alphanumeric strings, which are interned anyway. 

So it's fairly rare (but not completely impossible) to be using truly dynamic strings as keyword memes.

I moved the benchmarking code into a function to eliminate useless overhead and got this with Python 3.12:
```
kwargs1 - Cython:
f1: 2.0222100138198584 ms
f2: 2.5181209784932435 ms
f3: 2.3760879994370043 ms

kwargs1 - Python:
f1: 2.997796982526779 ms
f2: 3.2965060090646148 ms
f3: 3.7921319890301675 ms

kwargs2 - Cython:
f1: 31.21866300352849 ms
f2: 41.543947998434305 ms
f3: 52.85455100238323 ms

kwargs2 - Python:
f1: 35.062206006841734 ms
f2: 43.13900199485943 ms
f3: 55.39255900657736 ms
```
However, your code constructs a particularly bad case. It's rare that all keyword arguments of a function have length 1 and compare lexically after the declared argument names. In realistic code, the length will usually differ considerably, thus eliminating most of the string comparisons, and distinct ordering ranges should also be rare.

That said, ~we can certainly use the same trick as for the comparison against declared arguments and separate the pointer check from the comparison.~
EDIT: Misthink. We're expecting the names to *not* exist before, thus to compare unequal to all names we're testing. That's the issue here. Thus, a quick hash test would probably help since we can also quite safely assume all hash values to be unequal.
EDIT2: I think using the string hash is probably ok ‚Äì iff we're sure we have an exact str type as key. If it's a subtype, calculating the hash value might fail (it probably won't but it might). And even that's only assuming CPython-specific behaviour.

I also noticed that we're calling `PyErr_Occurred()` a lot due to the ambiguity of the negative `PyUnicode_Compare()` return value. But at least in CPython, the call cannot fail, according to the implementation:
https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/1b6bef8086e46e189cb9c4e46ac2945bc7848ed6/Objects/unicodeobject.c#L11314-L11328
https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/1b6bef8086e46e189cb9c4e46ac2945bc7848ed6/Objects/unicodeobject.c#L11166-L11280
We can probably avoid that check, even though it's slightly risky.
I added a hash value check (CPython-only) in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6684

Great improvement! Would it be beneficial as well to cache the unicode
length ? To avoid the overhead of function calls.

> ***@***.***>
>

> instance creation

I came up with an implementation. What's missing now is the case `kwds != NULL && kwds2 == NULL`. That's probably not as efficient as the others yet.

> > instance creation
> 
> I came up with an implementation. What's missing now is the case `kwds != NULL && kwds2 == NULL`. That's probably not as efficient as the others yet.

That's really great ! üëç 

Now if we were to go even further, here is the original use case I had when I opened #6676:
```
cdef class A:
    def __init__(self, *args, k1=1, k2=2, k3=3):
        return

    def __cinit__(self, p1, *args, **kwargs):
        return

cdef class B(A):
    def __init__(self, *args, k5=5, **kwargs):
        A.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)

    def __cinit__(self, p1, p2, *args, **kwargs):
        return

B(0, 1, k1=6, k2=7, k4=9, k5=1)
```

Here the `__cinit__` needs to access some parameters (thus cannot just be `__cinit__(self)` ), but they still need to declare `*args` and `**kwargs` to not raise an error when more parameters are present.

The code should run must faster with the changes, but we still end up with many dict copies:
- 1 copy is done in A's `__cinit__`, which calls __Pyx_ParseOptionalKeywords
- 1 copy is done in B's `__cinit__` (same reason)
- 2 copy is done in B's `__init__`. 1 during argument parsing (the new copy then pop scheme of `__Pyx_ParseOptionalKeywords`) and 1  when it calls `A.__init__` (it sends a copy).
- 1 copy is done in A's `__init__` (same reason as B for argument parsing)

Thus 5 copies, yet in this example None are needed. I don't know how much a copy costs in practice, but it would be a subsequent avenue to improve performance.

title: [ENH] Improving argument parsing when using **kwargs
